Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE ε4 allele. APOE is a major plasma lipid transporter. We also show that APOE4 increases the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with AD risk in part because of defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses. The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the Earth. The inner core is a mystery because its formation mechanism is unknown. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors. The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors. One of the most prominent is the failure of people to understand exponential growth. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related. Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and mortality. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results also suggest that the evolution of brain size is not a universal property of animals. This has important implications for the study of human evolution. Here, we show that ADF can induce torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous. We further found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our findings provide a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human ACE2 receptor at 8.3 Å resolution. We find that the D614G mutation has little effect on the overall structure of the spike, but does lead to a more open conformation that may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results will be important for vaccine design. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs. These are games in which the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even for finite games. The proof also yields a characterization of the set of tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has had a devastating impact on the US population. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, and at age 65 y by 0.87 y. These projections imply a 39% increase in the Black−White life expectancy gap, and a 30% reduction in the Latino−White gap. These findings have important implications for the future of the US population and its health.

Pressure is a powerful tool to control the chemical properties of matter. In this paper, we show that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a first step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the net effect is uncertain because of the complex interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that human ignitions and suppression can have a large effect on fire activity and carbon emissions. We find that reductions in human ignitions can reduce global warming by up to 10 y of CO2 emissions. This is important because of the large uncertainty in projections of future fire activity. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in shaping the future fire regime and its impact on climate. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy for the maintenance of mutualism. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan is sufficient to maintain a symbiotic relationship. This glycan is produced by the host and is catabolized by the symbiont. We propose that this strategy is used by hosts to control the activities of their symbionts. This mechanism may be widespread in nature. (Read more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics. We then use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Black Death, the most devastating epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe. However, this interpretation is challenged by the existence of multiple introductions of the bacterium into Europe, which are often assumed to have been caused by the arrival of rats. We show that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of the bacterium for centuries before the first plague outbreaks in Europe. Our results suggest that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into Europe, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This finding challenges the assumption that the Black Death was caused by a single introduction of Yersinia pestis. Our results also suggest that the Black Death was not a single event but rather a series of events. This interpretation is consistent with the hypothesis that the Black Death was caused by multiple introductions of Yersinia pestis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. They are also a critical prey species for many marine predators. Mass mortality events of asteroids have been reported in the past, but the cause of these events is still unknown. Here, we report the isolation of a densovirus from the tissues of affected asteroids. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a mass mortality event of asteroids. The discovery of this virus may have implications for the management of this important marine ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore a major challenge. We show here that a monoclonal antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is effective in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that the observed therapeutic effects are mediated by effector-cell–mediated cytotoxicity and that natural killer cells are a critical effector cell type. We further show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can also inhibit proliferation of primary AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other diseases with a similar mechanism of action. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean with a rich cultural and genetic heritage. We used a grid-based approach to sample genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous. We also find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We show that the RNA also interferes with the ability of a second small RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. These findings demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of small RNAs compete. This competition may be a general mechanism for the evolution of dual-function RNAs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines and treatments. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical. We show how to transform this information into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting model is robust across different crops, has nation-wide validity, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the design of agricultural monitoring systems and the development of early warning systems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is essential for communication. It is also a highly specialized domain, and it is not clear how the brain supports this ability. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is a major evolutionary event in the history of life. It is associated with the loss of photosynthesis and the acquisition of a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the evolution of plastid genomes in general and for the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus in particular. They also have implications for the evolution of the plastid genome in the model parasitic plant species Physcomitrella patens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in more than a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of this event by a factor of five to six. This increase is driven by a combination of a drying trend and a change in the frequency of extreme droughts. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results have implications for water resource management and food security in SSA. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized condensed matter physics. However, the discovery of quasicrystals in the laboratory has been slow. Here, we report the discovery of a quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first anthropogenic material to contain a quasicrystal. The discovery of this quasicrystal, which was formed in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, provides a unique link between the laboratory and the natural world. It also demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed in the laboratory and in nature. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is a highly efficient biological pathway on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase” reaction, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. Here, we show that the two enzymes are part of a larger family, and that the two classes of the cyclase reaction are evolutionarily related. We also show that the cyclase reaction is essential for oxygenic photosynthesis. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the cyclase reaction. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes. We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes ameliorated the disease severity in EAE. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages was critical for the generation and maintenance of disease. Activated astrocytes produced key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed that CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of EAE and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades. This increase is due to anthropogenic warming, which has increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. This finding has important implications for water resources management and climate change adaptation. It suggests that the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions will increase in the future. This is especially important in California, where the probability of drought has increased by a factor of ∼2 in the past 100 y. Our findings have implications for water resources management and climate change adaptation. They also highlight the importance of anthropogenic forcing in the observed changes in the probability of drought. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that behavioral inflexibility resulted from the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a potential target for drug development. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. These findings help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also highlight the potential for more positive content.

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) entry channel, the store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) or store-operated Ca2+ current (SOCC), is a major regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. Dysregulation of SOCE is implicated in a variety of diseases, including immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 that cause a congenital myopathy and thrombocytopenia. We show that these mutations cause constitutive activation of the SOCE channel, and that these mutations are associated with a congenital myopathy and thrombocytopenia. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the SOCE channel, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing neuronal death. The mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin spreads in a non–cell-autonomous manner in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that this spreading is dependent on endocytosis and fusion protein 1, and that it causes neuronal death. These results provide a model for the spreading of neurodegenerative proteins and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The bat is the only mammal capable of flying. Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the mechanisms that facilitate virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, named MTX, selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human cytosolic and mitochondrial serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT1/2). We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that this inhibitor is effective in B-cell lines, but paradoxically increases cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We hypothesize that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We are currently developing a clinical candidate for this indication. This work provides a proof-of-concept for a metabolic therapeutic approach to cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of proteins, including super-aggregation-prone proteins such as superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), the TDP-43 protein, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS). We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins. Rather, they are a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This metastable state may be a consequence of the disease-related loss of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. Our results may help to explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in various forms of ALS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal system is predicted to produce exotic quantum phenomena, including suppressed spontaneous emission, atom–light interaction anisotropy, and atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The photonic crystal system is fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. The photonic crystal system can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms. This work opens up a new platform for exploring exotic quantum phenomena in 2D photonic crystals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood. Some have proposed that the origin of the flowering plants was in a dark forest habitat, while others have proposed that the origin was in an open aquatic habitat. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from lithographic limestone deposits in the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. Montsechia has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology. However, the evolution of many viruses is poorly understood because of the difficulty in obtaining viral sequences from ancient remains. Here we present viral sequences from ancient remains of humans from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising globally, and this rise is accelerating. The acceleration is a result of the melting of glaciers and ice sheets and the expansion of ice in Antarctica and Greenland, and to a lesser extent, the warming of the oceans. The acceleration is also a result of the fact that the oceans are warming. The acceleration is not a result of human activities. We estimate the acceleration of global mean sea level to be 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This estimate is in agreement with the estimates of other studies. The estimate is also in agreement with the estimates of climate models. The estimate is also in agreement with the estimates of IPCC AR5 models.

Pain is a common and costly problem. We show that pain is increasing in the United States, with tomorrow’s elderly reporting less pain than today’s midlife. This is a mystery. We show that the erosion of working-class life is a plausible explanation.

The structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites are critical to understanding their function. NMR crystallography is a powerful tool for elucidating these properties, but its application in enzyme catalysis has been limited. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to characterize the structure and dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This integrated approach provides a detailed picture of the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. It also demonstrates the potential of this approach to study other important enzyme intermediates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment available. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment was highly effective in preventing disease and in reducing virus replication. These data support the further development of remdesivir as a treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses. Remdesivir may also be considered for a wider range of viruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel fashion. We show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont and for the acidification of the luminal environment. We propose that this glycan is a nutrient that is provisioned to the symbionts at night, when the squid is resting, and that its catabolism modulates the conditions in which the symbionts live. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiont populations and the conditions in which they live. It also suggests that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more common mechanism for the regulation of microbial communities than previously thought. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates are rising in the United States. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This change in mindset is associated with a reduction in suspensions. This intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion is error-free, whereas a dominant error-prone route is observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To infect human cells, MERS-CoV must first bind to cell receptors. We found that MERS-CoV infects human lung-derived cells only after the virus’s spike proteins are cleaved sequentially during their secretion from virus-producing cells. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The first cleavages are also significant because they expand MERS-CoV tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection. Therefore, the first cleavages may be significant determinants of the pathogenicity of other viruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the global population are a key driver of this problem. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering operation can have a large impact on sales. This is a simple and cost-effective way to make a difference. The results also suggest that nudging people to make more sustainable food choices may be possible. This is an important step toward achieving the goal of a sustainable food system.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is a critical component of the cancer cell. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast cancer cell line expressing oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We also show that the surfaceome can be used as a biomarker for the oncogene. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion. This work suggests possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout. It also does not appear to increase either party’s vote share. Finally, vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings also have implications for the design of future vote-by-mail programs.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the world. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8. We show that the structure is similar to SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, but with a unique dimerization interface. We also show that the structure is unique to SARS-CoV-2, with no homology to other known proteins. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis for the severity and spread of the disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a molecular understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is full of associations. We want to know which ones are strong. But we don’t want to be fooled by spurious associations. We want to be able to declare a strong association when we find one. This paper describes a way to do this.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the formation of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs is difficult, and the therapeutic application of ECs is limited. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells from human fibroblasts by using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). The ETV2-induced endothelial cells exhibit vascular characteristics in vitro and in vivo. This study provides a promising approach for the generation of ECs and their application in the treatment of vascular disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK are frequently mutated in human cancers. In addition, the two ligands encoded by the human genome are physiological ligands of ALK and LTK. Here, we show that zebrafish possess three augmentor genes that are essential for pigment patterning. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and LTK and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate LTK in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These findings provide insights into the evolution of the ligand system and the role of augmentors in the development of the zebrafish. They also provide a model system for further exploration of the role of augmentors in human development. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. The molecular mechanisms of T2D are still poorly understood. Herein, we report a role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. We also provide evidence that STING is required for β-cell function. These findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging of the viral genome is a fundamental process for the production of infectious virions. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings could help to understand the evolution of influenza A viruses. (Read more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to vascular obstruction and death. The underlying mechanisms of atherogenesis are not fully understood. Here, we report that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is essential for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This strategy may be useful for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have dramatically altered the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire. Human-caused wildfires have expanded the geographic and seasonal fire niche in the United States, and have increased the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. This expansion has been driven by human activities, including the development of the western United States and the expansion of the agricultural frontier into the wildland-urban interface. Actions to reduce the risk of human-caused wildfires should be a priority for United States policy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus that causes microcephaly and other neurological complications in newborns. We present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the time between cell infection and viral production is short, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is long. We also show that antiviral treatment can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can be used to guide the design of antiviral treatment strategies. Coral bleaching is a major threat to the health of coral reefs. It is caused by the loss of the symbiotic zooxanthellae, which are the main source of energy and growth-limiting nutrients for the host coral. The underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the catabolism of amino acids is a key process in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. This process is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the intestinal microbiome and trigger a regenerative response that promotes tumor growth. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome can restore barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our findings highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our study provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between tumorigenesis and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the main treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. We show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with breast cancer stemness. Finally, we show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can improve the response to chemotherapy in a mouse model of breast cancer. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in breast cancer patients. This approach may be particularly useful in patients with breast cancer that is resistant to chemotherapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion. This event is unique in the record of volcanic eruptions and ozone depletion and is not associated with a change in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. The coincidence of these events and their impact on climate and the ozone layer provide a plausible explanation for the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. This finding has implications for the causes of the ozone hole and the start of the recent global warming hiatus. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We estimate that 158 million people rely on inland fisheries for all or most of their animal protein. We show that river fisheries are concentrated in regions of high biodiversity and ecosystem stress. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of freshwater fisheries and to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity. Our findings highlight the importance of inland fisheries for food security and biodiversity conservation.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is limited by the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The adult mammalian nervous system is incapable of regenerating after injury. This inability is a major obstacle to restoring function after injury. We report a form of regeneration in C. elegans that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery opens the door to a new platform for discovering factors that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. We also show that this capacity is enhanced by disrupting calcium channels and elevating cAMP levels. These findings are important for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. They also have implications for restoring function after injury in the mammalian CNS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Recombination is a fundamental process in the evolution of genomes. It is also a source of genetic variation. In this study, we use a population of wild monkeyflowers to map the locations of recombination events in a flowering plant. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions never recombining. We also find that recombination is more likely to occur near the start of genes. These results are similar to those found in yeast and in mice. Thus, the patterns of recombination we describe may be ancient and conserved. This article is protected by copyright. The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal reflecting the activity of a large number of functionally interconnected neuronal populations. The functional organization of this system is not known. We used metabolic imaging to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. We also found that the default mode network was already present at diagnosis in Alzheimer’s disease patients. These results provide a direct view of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. They have implications for the development of new imaging biomarkers and for the design of new therapeutic strategies. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

RNA modifications are important for gene regulation. Here we describe a 5′ cap structure in eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA) that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). We show that NAD+ is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. NAD+ mRNAs are produced cotranscriptionally, suggesting that NAD+ is added to the 5′ end of nascent mRNA. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of 5′ RNA modifications in gene regulation. Copyright © 2015. Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that DNA methylation at specific loci is altered in blood cells from people with diabetes and that this alteration is associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that gut permeability is increased in alcohol-dependent subjects. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also shows that gut dysfunction is associated with psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. These results may help to understand the pathophysiology of alcohol dependence and to develop new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The tomato is a model system for studying fruit ripening and the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of these compounds are not known. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce these compounds. This pathway is unique to tomato and is distinct from other known flavin-dependent monooxygenases in plants. Understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds will be important for improving the flavor of tomato fruit. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that these threats interact to reduce the capacity of ecosystems to maintain ecosystem functions. We demonstrate that the impacts of environmental warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of climate change on biodiversity in the context of the functional integrity of ecosystems. This is important because biodiversity loss is often considered in isolation from other threats. Our findings have implications for the design of conservation strategies and the management of ecosystems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode a map of local space, but the organization of its neurons is unknown. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for navigation, are organized separately from other neurons. This suggests that grid cells might have a unique role in creating a map of local space. Our findings have implications for understanding the neural basis of navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. The dopamine system is critical to movement and motivation. Here, we show that dopamine-containing neurons in the nigrostriatum are integrated by specialized formations within the dopamine-containing system. These formations, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are composed of striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites. They are densely innervated by a variety of afferents and are connected to the striatum. We suggest that striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. We all feel connected to others. But how do we know when we feel connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. This signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are responsible for setting the heart rate and are critical for maintaining a normal heart rate in health and disease. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs), which are responsible for setting the heart rate. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SANC automaticity. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN function. Our results reveal that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of SANCs by modulating the content of Ca2+ stores and the surface expression of ion channels. These findings provide insight into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for treating heart failure. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice. This effect is dependent on jasmonate (JA) signaling. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote rice defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. Our results suggest that the ability to access rare combinations of chemical concentrations may be a key factor in the evolution of complex systems. This article is protected by copyright. Autoimmune encephalitis is a rapidly growing cause of seizures in children. The most common cause is antibodies against the NMDA receptor. We show that these antibodies can change the way the brain is wired, and that this can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This is a major advance in understanding the mechanisms of this devastating disease. It also offers a potential therapeutic target.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event. To understand the causes and consequences of such events, we need to know how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. This event may have contributed to the extinction of the dinosaurs and other species. Understanding the causes and consequences of this event can help us understand the risks associated with the current warming. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation. Certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate commitments to reduce deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Our results suggest that certification can be an effective tool to reduce deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a large protein complex involved in the final steps of exocytosis. Dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases. However, the study of the exocyst complex is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes in the model organisms. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This article is protected by copyright. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a major area of study. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In some species, multiple sex determination alleles interact to produce more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be increased by introgression of a new sex determination allele. These results have implications for understanding the evolution and maintenance of sex determination alleles. They also have implications for understanding the evolution of sexual dimorphism. The retina is a unique tissue that is challenged by multiple sources of reactive oxygen species. The retina contains a unique redox system that is able to protect against photooxidative damage. However, this system is challenged by the accumulation of reactive intermediates of vitamin A. We show that the redox system in the retina is challenged by the presence of iron. This finding has implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. Our findings also have implications for the treatment of other retinal diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use specialized side branches (tentacles) armed with nematocysts for prey capture. These tentacles are organized in a modular fashion, with each branch armed with a different type of nematocyst. We show that siphonophores can evolve from one prey type to another, and that the evolution of nematocysts is linked to the evolution of the whole tentacle. Our findings help understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human hand is a complex structure with a wide range of functions. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolutionary biology. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This fossil and its implications for the evolution of the human hand are discussed. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease. Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human cytosolic and mitochondrial serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT). We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that this inhibitor is effective in B-cell lines, but paradoxically increases cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We propose that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer. It also provides a lead for a metabolic drug for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing number of people suffering from undernutrition and a growing number suffering from overweight and obesity. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. This is important because people’s diets are a key determinant of their health. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and health. This study also highlights the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets. This is particularly important in low- and middle-income countries where the majority of the world’s forests are located.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it is also a major cause of soil degradation. We show that the increase in farm machinery capacity has led to a propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers. This has the potential to reduce soil productivity, and we provide a global map of subsoil compaction susceptibility. We also show that the total weight of modern farm vehicles is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that unconstrained roaming of these giants would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. We hypothesize that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This suggests that the evolution of animal behavior may have played a role in the development of agricultural practices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
